keyTakeAways: A man named Billy Joe Cagle, a convicted felon from Cartersville, Georgia, was arrested at Hartsfield-Jackson Atlanta International Airport after his family alerted police that he planned to 'shoot it up' on a live social media stream.
Cagle was found in possession of an AR-15 assault rifle and 27 rounds of ammunition in his Chevrolet pickup truck parked outside the airport terminal.
Police confirmed that Cagle had a premeditated plan to inflict harm on a large number of people, described as a terroristic threat with intent to commit aggravated assault.
The incident was averted due to timely intervention by family members who reported his online threats, demonstrating the critical role of community vigilance in public safety.

Cagle has been charged with making terroristic threats, criminal attempt to commit aggravated assault, possession of a firearm during the commission of a felony, and possession of a firearm by a felon.
The case underscores how mental health struggles, such as schizophrenia, may intersect with violent intentions and the need for early intervention and support systems.
Federal authorities are investigating how Cagle obtained the firearm, which authorities state he was not legally allowed to possess.
The event was praised by local officials, including Mayor Andre Dickens and Homeland Security Secretary Kristi Noem, as a success due to timely reporting and swift law enforcement action.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Billy Joe Cagle, a 49-year-old convicted felon from Cartersville, Georgia, was arrested at Hartsfield-Jackson Atlanta International Airport after his family alerted police that he had posted on a live social media stream announcing his intent to 'shoot it up' at the airport. Officers found an AR-15 assault rifle and 27 rounds of ammunition in his Chevrolet pickup truck parked outside the terminal. Cagle, who reportedly had schizophrenia and was taking medication, was taken into custody after being observed near the TSA checkpoint. He has been charged with making terroristic threats, criminal attempt to commit aggravated assault, and illegal firearm possession. The incident, which could have resulted in widespread casualties given the airport’s global scale, was averted due to early reporting by family members and swift law enforcement action. Authorities are investigating how Cagle obtained the weapon, which he was not legally allowed to possess. Public figures, including Mayor Andre Dickens and U.S. Homeland Security Secretary Kristi Noem, praised the successful intervention, highlighting the critical role of community vigilance, mental health awareness, and timely law enforcement response.
title: Man Arrested at Atlanta Airport After Social Media Threat to 'Shoot It Up'
